1.text: Moreover the LORD answered Job, and said,

2.text: Shall he that cavilleth contend with the Almighty? he that argueth with God, let him answer it.

3.text: Then Job answered the LORD, and said,

4.text: Behold, I am of small account; what shall I answer thee? I lay mine hand upon my mouth.

5.text: Once have I spoken, and I will not answer; yea twice, but I will proceed no further.

6.text: Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind, and said,

7.text: Gird up thy loins now like a man: I will demand of thee, and declare thou unto me.

8.text: Wilt thou even disannul my judgment? wilt thou condemn me, that thou mayest be justified?

9.text: Or hast thou an arm like God? and canst thou thunder with a voice like him?

10.text: Deck thyself now with excellency and dignity; and array thyself with honour and majesty.

11.text: Pour forth the overflowings of thine anger: and look upon every one that is proud, and abase him.

12.text: Look on every one that is proud, and bring him low; and tread down the wicked where they stand.

13.text: Hide them in the dust together; bind their faces in the hidden place.

14.text: Then wilt I also confess of thee that thine own right hand can save thee.

15.text: Behold now behemoth, which I made with thee; he eateth grass as all ox.

16.text: Lo now, his strength is in his loins, and his force is in the muscles of his belly.

17.text: He moveth his tail like a cedar: the sinews of his thighs are knit together.

18.text: His bones are as tubes of brass; his limbs are like bars of iron.

19.text: He is the chief of the ways of God: he only that made him can make his sword to approach unto him.

20.text: Surely the mountains bring him forth food; where all the beasts of the field do play.

21.text: He lieth under the lotus trees, in the covert of the reed, and the fen.

22.text: The lotus trees cover him with their shadow; the willows of the brook compass him about.

23.text: Behold, if a river overflow, he trembleth not: he is confident, though Jordan swell even to his mouth.

24.text: Shall any take him when he is on the watch, or pierce through his nose with a snare?
